Award.AwardTitle: Free Standing Flexible Lithium-Ion Polymer Electrolyte Membranes formed by Photopolymerization
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The principal objectives of this project are (1) to demonstrate how the fundamental understanding of ternary phase diagrams may provide guidance to facile fabrication of free-standing flexible polymer batteries and (2) to elucidate governing principles for creation of periodic arrays of ionic channels aligned homeotropically via photolithography and having well defined domain size and periodicity. These aligned channels produced by photopolymerization-induced phase separation will not only serve as ion conducting wires (or micro-channels), but also increase the ion concentration without sacrificing the mechanical strength and integrity of the free-standing battery membranes. Such periodic arrays of channels with perpendicular orientation have been highly sought for enhanced electron/exciton transport in the development of organic materials for solar cell applications as well as for efficient Li+ ion transport in rechargeable polymer batteries.

This project focuses on determination of the eutectic phase diagram as a means of suppressing and/or eliminating undesirable constituent crystals in the binary and ternary mixture of polyethylene glycol diacrylate (PEGDA)/succinonitrile (SCN)/lithium bis-(trifluoromethylsufonyl)imide (LiTFSI). The uniqueness of the present system is that photolithographic crosslinking of PEGDA not only affords improved mechanical strength and integrity of the networks, but also increases the ion transport through the unperturbed channels. Moreover, the aligned oriented channel structure will also increase the ion storage capacity due to increase in interface areas and complexation with nitrile groups of SCN. Another advantage is that SCN can effectively ionize the ionic salts and also completely eliminate the undesirable LiTFSI crystals. More importantly, the fabricated polymer electrolyte membrane is a free-standing film that requires no organic solvent and has a high conductivity (7.1x10-3 S/cm) at ambient temperature. The fabricated polymer electrolyte membrane may be operated over a wide temperature range, from 40-80 deg C.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The goal of this project is to study and develop lightweight and rechargeable free-standing polymer lithium ion batteries for "green" electric vehicles. Unlike conventional electrolyte batteries, the present polymer electrolyte membrane contains no toxic or flammable organic solvent and thus the safety issue such as solvent leakage or battery combustion may be avoided. The present polymer electrolyte is moldable in any shape or form, and thus it should find broader utility. The strategy of the perpendicular alignment of cylindrical columnar morphology along the film thickness direction will further improve ion transport through the channels and enhance ion storage capacity due to increase in surface/interface areas. The knowledge thus acquired can be transferred beyond the scope of the current project, specifically to development of organic materials for solar cells and photo-optical switching in information technology. This project will educate graduate and undergraduate students who will be exposed to multi-disciplinary research in polymer materials science, engineering mathematics, and electrochemistry. The research outcomes will be disseminated to the public through the PI's website or distance-learning programs of the Akron Global Polymer Academy, which conducts workshops for high-school science teachers and their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technical Merits:

The present project has succeded in producing completely amorphous, solid state polymer electrolyte membrane (ss-PEM) for lithium ion battery via photopolylmerization of polymer precursor (PEGDA) in the isotropic melt state of the lithium salt (LITFSI)/plasticizer (SCN) mixture without requiring any solvent. Of particular importance is that the above ss-PEM showed very high room temperature ionic conductivity on the level of superionic conductors (i.e. >1E-3 S/cm). Moreover, it exhibited excellent thermal stability up to 200 oC investigated with flame retardant and self-extinguishable properties, thereby alleviating fire hazard notoriously known for combustion of conventional lithium ion batteries that contained flammable liquid electrolyte. In the heating and cooling cycles from ambient temperature to 140 oC, several compositions of the PEM (PEGDA/SCN/LiTFSI) showed the sustained high ionic conductivity that reached the level of 1E-2 S/cm at elevated temperatures. In addition, the PEM revealed excellent electrochemical stability from -0.5 to 4.5 V versus Li/Li+. More importantly, the present PEM is compatible with standard lithium metal oxide electrodes such as LiFePO4 and Li4Ti5O12. Half cells composed of these two electrodes against lithium reference electrode revealed specific capacity close to the theoretical value. As typical for most PEMs, there was slight capacity fading (or decay) to about 15-20% after 50 cycles. Recently, the PI's group has found that this capacity fading issue may be alleviated by stabilizing with addition of 0.4 wt% LiBOB. The present PEM shows a stable trend of ionic conducitvity during isothermal annealing at 135 oC for 150 mins investigated; and is fire retardant and self-extinguishable in the flame test. Moreover, the present PEMs are shape conformable and thus provide various battery design possibilities including flexible cable or film shape, among others. The present ss-PEM has met most requirments for cathode applications in low-to-moderate power lithium ion battery. For high energy and high power battery in electric and hybrid vehicles, surface modification of silicon and/or carbonaceous anodes are still in progress that involves grafting of hyperbranched polymeric supramolecules having high populations of active groups on the surfaces of mesoporous carbon, carbon nanotube (CNT), graphene oxide (GO) sheets as a means of increasing the ion storage capacity.

Broader Impact:

One student (Mauricio Echeverri) graduated with a Ph.D. in Polymer engineering and is employed at Kent Displays, Inc., Kent, Ohio. Another student (Ms. Ruixuan He) is expected to graduate at the end of coming fall semester, 2016. Two master's students (Mr. Guopeng Fu and Mr. Jinwei Cao) graduated with M. S. in Polymer Engineering in 2013 and 2014, respectively. One undergraduate student (Ms. Tianli Ren) graduated with a B.S. degree in 2016. Three REU students (Mr. D. Ward, Chemical Engineering, Miami University; Ms. Mireille Mballa, Electrical Engineering, Penn State University; Ms. Janel Dempsey, Chemistry, John Carrol University) and two undergraduate students (Mr. Camilo Piedrahita, Chemistry, University of Antioquia, Colombia and Ms. Cosette Hamad, Chemistry, University of Akron) received research training in the PI's laboratory. Mr. Guopeng Fu, Jinwei Cao and Camilo Piedrahita are now Ph.D. candidates in Polymer Engineering. The PI's group has collaborated with Professors Y. Tsukahara and K. Adachi of Kyoto Institue of Technology in the synthesis of hyperbranched and arborescent PEG supramolecules and surface modification of CNT for battery anodes. The goal is to increase storage capacity via increase of the concentration of ether side groups in the PEM network. Mr. Kosuke Izaki, a visiting exchange student from KIT, received graduate student intership at the PI's laboratory from September 2014-March 2015. Kyu's group is currently collaborating internally with Professor Yu Zhu's group (Department of Polymer Science, University of Akron) in the development of vertically aligned CNT to improve the storage capacity and stability in the charge-discharge cycling. All participating graduate and undergraduate students received interdisciplinary research experience in the development of solid-state superionic polymer electrolyte membrane for lithium ion battery. Their acquired knowledge and technical skills in science and engineering will be of paramount importance for future workforce.
